qas.question: What is the former name of the Arthur M. Sackler Museum?
How many museums does the Busch-Reisinger Museum comprise?
Who designed the Fogg Museum of Art?
What kind of French art is kept at the Arthur M. Sackler Museum?
What glass flowers exhibit is included in the Busch-Reisinger Museum?

context: Harvard operates several arts, cultural, and scientific museums. The Harvard Art Museums comprises <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b4_0>three<b4_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/> museums.<a0_0/> The Arthur M. Sackler Museum includes collections of ancient, Asian, Islamic and later Indian art, the Busch-Reisinger Museum, formerly <b3_0>the Germanic Museum<b3_0/>, covers central and northern European art, and the Fogg Museum of Art, covers <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>Western art from the Middle Ages to the present<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> emphasizing Italian early Renaissance, British pre-Raphaelite, and <b6_0>19th-century<b6_0/> French art. The Harvard Museum of Natural History includes the Harvard Mineralogical Museum, Harvard University Herbaria featuring the <b7_0>Blaschka<b7_0/> Glass Flowers exhibit, and the Museum of Comparative Zoology. Other museums include the Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts, designed by <b5_0>Le Corbusier<b5_0/>, housing the film archive, the <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, specializing in the cultural history and civilizations of the Western Hemisphere, and the Semitic Museum featuring artifacts from excavations in the Middle East.
